ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: some linear algebra
The basics of multivariable calculus and linear algebra
An understanding of the concepts in multi and linalg that are most important for econ and other social sciences
I learned about the basics of multivariable calculus and linear algebra, and some applications that could be relevant to future Economics courses.
Multivariable calculus, some linear algebra, and some applications of both topics to economics.
Theoretical and practical approach of Multivariable calculus and Linear Algebra.
Calculus that will be applicable to my future studying of economics

I learned about vectors and matrices, including how to multiply them with dot product, cross product, and matrix multiplication. I learned basic 3D geometry, including equations of planes and lines in R3, and i learned how to find tangent points or directions of greatest increase. I learned how to do maximization problems.
Some multi and some linear. Nothing too advanced
- knowledge about calculus and linear algebra
multivariable calculus and linear algebra (vector properties, linearization, hessian borders, Lagrange multipliers, matrices)
Learned about functions of multiple variables and how we can work with big sets of information using matrices.
Introduction to multivariable

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: the lectures were so confusing and disorganized, it was hard to follow what was going on because I didn't know why things were being said

I like that the course offers a broad introduction to both calculus and linear algebra and I thought the combination of P-sets  and exams was well managed. The course was a little disorganized at times but otherwise very insightful.
Bobby is amazing

Strengths: super chill, professor is literally the best (but hes leaving unfortunately), exams were all relatively straightforward and not difficult, final project was very chill, overall a good class
Weaknesses: wish we covered the last topics fully in class instead of having to learn it ourselves (but the exam fortunately involved a walkthrough of it), would also be nice to have things a bit more organized

I really liked how we got to learn how these mathematical concepts are applied to other subjects and the basis of many formulas we learn. It felt a lot less theoretical than a lot of other math classes. However, problem sets were sometimes a bit long and grading on the problem sets happened a bit slowly, so it was hard to see if you had a good grasp on everything.

Introduces us to Multivariable calculus and Linear Algebra to an extend that is useful for Economics student.
Maybe include more practical application in the field of Economics?
I felt the course material was very good and applicable to what I will need to know in the future

Strengths: Material was covered in detail with readings given in written form. There were plenty of resources and exercises available. The workload was light because Bobby cared about our mental health, and he made sure that we were not too stressed out. He made himself accessible on Zoom or online, and granted extensions when necessary. This was legitimately the best math course Ive ever taken at Yale.
- great course, good structure
Bobby was a great professor. The only weakness of the class was the lack of structure at times.
there was no feedback. Please fix this.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: if you need math for the econ major i would reccomend this course, if not don't take it
Great math class for non math majors. Very easy and chill :) Take for the econ prereq instead of 120!!

Yes. If you want a math class that is fewer students and you get to ask questions, take this class. Its a good introduction into multivariable calc and linear algebra and I enjoyed it. I think it was a much better decision for me than 115 or 120

Absolutely, if you're an econ major/social science major that is already familiar with AP Calculus BC-level math and want to do one more math for prerequisite purposes. Definitely a much chiller math course than most others (but you cant take other higher level math after this)
Yes, especially if they are Econ majors who are considering Math 120 but are unsure if they should take it.
For Econ Majors, absolutely. The class makes it clear why many math concepts matter in practice.
Yes if they are planning on majoring in economics
I will definitely recommend this course taught by especially Bobby McDonald. He is the most relaxed math professor you will ever get and he will be so understanding of you and your mental health.
Personally, would have wanted it a little more challenging/interesting
Yes I definitely would

yes, if you do not want to take 120 but want some of the skills. If you want more in-depth knowledge then just take multi and linear separately. If you are an Econ major, we did not really go over applications so the class was not as useful in that sense.
No. There is no feedback and the lectures were a little disorganized.
